content.body: weird question but is it possible to make cursor sprites in css or i'm left only with cursor:none and JS and tracking cursor position?

If you have an svg sprite-sheet you might be able to use something like `cursor: url("data:image/svg+xml,<svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' width='32' height='32'><use href="sprites.svg#icon"></use></svg>")`
content.formatted_body: If you have an svg sprite-sheet you might be able to use something like cursor: url("data:image/svg+xml,<svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' width='32' height='32'><use href="sprites.svg#icon"></use></svg>")

content.body: it's png sized 128px*128px and each tile is 32x32â€¦
perfect for background-image hack but possibly not cursorâ€¦
Yea, I think you can do that with `object-position`
content.formatted_body: Yea, I think you can do that with object-position

content.body: Ah cursor sprites, not sure

if you sliced the images you could put them all in an svg as image embeds. You'd still end up with one resource, even if it's a bit hacky. But having said that I don't know if `<use>` in an svg cursor image will work.
content.formatted_body: if you sliced the images you could put them all in an svg as image embeds. You'd still end up with one resource, even if it's a bit hacky. But having said that I don't know if <use> in an svg cursor image will work.

content.body: yup. cursor imageâ€¦
the one which changes to hand icon when over link
i don't want to sliceâ€¦
i'll quicker do cursor:none + JSâ€¦

annevk: given foolip has approved I wondered if you had time to do one last pass on https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9841 ? While I have the time I'd love to be able to address any last review comments.

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: `<(div|fieldset)[^>]+role=["']?radiogroup` should work, I think
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: <(div|fieldset)[^>]+role=["']?radiogroup should work, I think

content.body:
well actually, I guess it would be also be good to have the data for two as separate queries; so:

`<div[^>]+role=["']?radiogroup`
`<fieldset[^>]+role=["']?radiogroup`
content.formatted_body:
well actually, I guess it would be also be good to have the data for two as separate queries; so:

content.body: The total is 0.01%, running the separate ones
Thanks!

1	136	                 div+fieldset
2	3500	        fieldset
3	58782	        div
4	672552031	neither
ah, excellent â€” double thanks
672552031 is the total number of documents in the entire archive?

keithamus: annevk : was the naming of `commandForElement` vs `commandFor` discussed? Most existing IDL attributes in HTML that return an element (or null) don't have `Element` suffix
content.formatted_body: keithamus: annevk : was the naming of commandForElement vs commandFor discussed? Most existing IDL attributes in HTML that return an element (or null) don't have Element suffix

content.body: zcorpan: it was modelled after `popoverTargetElement`.
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: it was modelled after popoverTargetElement.

content.body: keithamus: ok
content.formatted_body: keithamus: ok

content.body: that's not necessarily an objection to your comment, but I don't think the question has been raised before. Naming was discussed quite extensively (it used to be `invokeTargetElement`) but no one raised questions around the `Element` suffix IIRC.
content.formatted_body: that's not necessarily an objection to your comment, but I don't think the question has been raised before. Naming was discussed quite extensively (it used to be invokeTargetElement) but no one raised questions around the Element suffix IIRC.

content.body: zcorpan: all IDL attributes that are Element(s)-reflecting should have such a suffix
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: all IDL attributes that are Element(s)-reflecting should have such a suffix

content.body: annevk: ok, I've missed that
content.formatted_body: annevk: ok, I've missed that

content.body: `CommandEvent source` doesn't have an `Element` suffix
content.formatted_body: CommandEvent source doesn't have an Element suffix

content.body: I think the aria reflection stuff all has Element / Elements suffixes too
Neither does target etc, I think was the logic there (if there was any)
* Neither does target etc, I think was the logic there (if there was any). It was named source based on the option bag added to showPopover/togglePopover.

m.new_content.body: Neither does target etc, I think was the logic there (if there was any). It was named source based on the option bag added to showPopover/togglePopover.

content.body:
* Neither does target etc, I think was the logic there (if there was any). It was named source based on the option bag added to showPopover/togglePopover.

It's also readonly as opposed to the others which do two way reflection.

m.new_content.body:
Neither does target etc, I think was the logic there (if there was any). It was named source based on the option bag added to showPopover/togglePopover.

It's also readonly as opposed to the others which do two way reflection.

content.body: keithamus: show modal dialog can throw an exception, e.g. if element is not connected. Is that ok? Example: https://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/13512
content.formatted_body: keithamus: show modal dialog can throw an exception, e.g. if element is not connected. Is that ok? Example: https://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/13512

content.body: Ah we should probably check if the element is connected just before showing as modal I guess
content.formatted_body: Ah we should probably check if the element is connected just before showing as modal I guess

content.body: zcorpan: `CommandEvent` doesn't use reflect, so it's not applicable?
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: CommandEvent doesn't use reflect, so it's not applicable?

content.body: annevk: true. But then https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-navigateevent-sourceelement was recently added
content.formatted_body: annevk: true. But then https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-navigateevent-sourceelement was recently added

content.body: keithamus: the other possibility is that the document is not fully active, but I think the button will have the same node document, and the activation behavior steps check for that (step 2). So I think connected is the only missing case
content.formatted_body: keithamus: the other possibility is that the document is not fully active, but I think the button will have the same node document, and the activation behavior steps check for that (step 2). So I think connected is the only missing case

content.body: I can file a bug
https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/11043
We could alternatively do the same as popover? Have a way to turn exceptions into early returns?
* We could alternatively do the same as popover? Have a way to turn exceptions into early returns? Though that's a bit messy so just adding the check might be nicer

m.new_content.body: We could alternatively do the same as popover? Have a way to turn exceptions into early returns? Though that's a bit messy so just adding the check might be nicer

content.body: zcorpan: I think `sourceElement` there is reasonable because there's multiple types of sources, but we only expose it for elements.
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: I think sourceElement there is reasonable because there's multiple types of sources, but we only expose it for elements.

content.body: IIUC, you can now do `<form><button command=... commandfor=...>` (without `type`), and it will be a command button instead of a submit button
content.formatted_body: IIUC, you can now do <form><button command=... commandfor=...> (without type), and it will be a command button instead of a submit button

content.body: It'll currently be a no-op
But in future it can be a command button instead of submit
(Unless I can't remember the details which at this point wouldn't be surprising ðŸ˜…)
The reasoning is that in older browsers it will submit the form still so this encourages you to add an explicit type
